title: Circular Head Saints searching for normality , further development | The Advocate
body_text:
A $700,500 redevelopment of the playing surface at Circular Head Recreation Ground will give the Saints their "first chance at normality" this season.

The ground, which has been likened to a boggy quagmire in the middle of winter, has undergone major restoration works to improve the drainage and reliability of the surface.
And club secretary Keith Billing hoped that it would provide some stability for players, volunteers and supporters who have been forced to give away or transfer home games in the past.
"We're just looking forward to having a hopefully normal year where we can have a home and away game routine like every other club," Billing said.
"Our facilities are great but there's still complications with sharing it with the community.
"While we haven't got those major issues of having to keep our facilities up to scratch, we are forever in negotiation mode with the body that runs the ground.
"We'll have the full nine teams this year. We're craving bit of normality and hopefully this redevelopment will allow that."
The Saints will begin their season at home for the first time since returning to the competition in 2022, and will face East Devonport on Saturday, April 12.
Billing praised the Circular Head Council for recognising the severity of the problem, and thanked the company responsible for providing a magnificent surface.
As for further developments at the ground, Billing shared what he would like to see.
"Looking into the future, what we need is a bit of expansion to accommodate women's football," he said.
"For us, we're only entering our second year [in that competition]. So whether it will be sustainable, and the council will want proof of that, I dare say.
"But there's always an air of uncertainty because we're negotiating with the council."
The restoration work has been recognised by AFL Tasmania, with the project named the 2024 Ken Gannon Community Football Facilities award for the state.
